Conical Pendulum.description: A conical pendulum rotates in a horizontal circle. Adjust the **velocity** to see the angle change. Red = Tension, Green = Weight.
questions: What happens to the angle theta as velocity increases?
Derive the relationship between tension and angular velocity.

Vertical Circular Motion.description: Observe tension variations at the top and bottom of the vertical path.
questions: Why is the tension minimum at the top
Which position is the string likely to break?

Banked Circular Motion.description: Animation shows a banked track with components of normal reaction providing centripetal force
questions: Q1. How does speed affect the angle of banking?
Q2. How does friction contribute to centripetal force?
Q3. Is friction pointing upward or downward?

Play Ground Ride.description: Animation shows the angle of inclination from the vertical at different distances from the centre of rotation.
questions: Q1. Do all the rides have the same angular velocity?
Q2. Do all the rides have the same linear speed?
Q3. How do the angles change with angular velocity?

Ferris Wheel.description: Animations shows the forces acting on the object on the seat of a ferris wheel.
questions: Q1 Can the friction be zero?
Q2 At what position is the normal reaction maximum?

Glider.description: Animation sows a glider in horizontal circular motion
questions: Q1 What happens to the angle of inclination of the glider wings if the speed is higher?

Wall of death.description: ANimation shows an object moving in horizontal circular motion on a vertical wall
questions: Q1 If the wall has no friction, is it possible to move in a horizontal circular motion.
Q2 What happens to the angle of the object (e.g. motorcycle) if the speed is higher?

General Projectile.description: Vary launch height and angle to see the trajectory.
questions: Can the horizontal velocity become zero in the presence of air resistance?
Why is the time taken to fall longer than the time to rise in the presence of air resistance?

Hunter & Monkey.description: Classic problem: Independence of horizontal and vertical motion.
questions: What happens if there is no gravity?
Will the bullet still hit the monkey if the experiment is repeated on the Moon?

Circular 2 source.description: Note how the separation of maxima changes by changing the source sepration and the wavelength.

Two source.description:
The blue and green wave sources meet at a point. The resultant displacement is shown by the red sphere. 
Adjust the relative phase difference, amplitude and frequency to see how the resultant displacement changes.

Two transverse waves.description:
Superposition of 2 transverse waves.
Adjust the amplitude, phase difference, path length to see how the resultant displacement changes.

Longitudinal Standing.description:
Simulation shows the addition of 2 longitudinal waves in opposite directions gives rise to a standing (red) wave with nodes (white).
Adjust the wavelength to see how the separation of nodes changes.

Transverse Standing.description: Simulation shows the formation of transverse standing wave from 2 transverse waves travelling in opposite directions.

Longitudinal.description: Animation shows a longitudinal wave. The particles oscillate about the equilibrium position along the direction of the wave. They do not travel forward with the wave.
questions: What is the phase difference between pressure and displacement?

Transverse.description: The particles oscillate in the direction perpendicular to the wave. The particles do not travel with the wave,

One polariser.description: An unpolarised transverse wave passes through a polariser. A polarised wave is formed along the direction of the polarising filter.
questions: What is the intensity of the polarised light compared to the incident intensity?

Two polarisers.description: The unpolarised light passes through the first polariser to produce a plane polarised light. This plane polarised light passess through a second polariser. The emerging plane polarised light follows the polarisation direction of the second polariser. The intensity of the final polarised light varies with the angle between the two polarisers.
questions: What are the possible angles for the final intensity to be zero?

Three polariser.description: A vertically polarised light can be rotated into horizontally polarised light.
